BE11:20am

Oh, ICAG?

PM11:21am

Yeah, Q3s here https://www.invest...1710270700487727U/

11:21 am
BE11:21am

Yeah, results aren't awful.

BE11:21am

But the shares travelled before arriving and there's nothing in the way of upgrades

BE11:22am

If anything, consensus is drifting a tad lower.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

Let me grab Morgan Stanley to summarise where we are.

PM11:22am

Think people are fretting about the dividend

BE11:22am

IAG reported 3Q17 RASK ex FX trends (up 2.2%) lower than 2Q17 exit rates (where constant currency RASK was up 3.7%). Total revenues of €6.617bn rose 2.0% in the quarter, helped by cargo and other revenue trends. Reported unit cost ex fuel performance was positive - down 1.7% helped by €154m of FX tailwinds YoY. €1,455m pre-exceptional EBIT was modestly ahead of MSe €1,424m / cons. €1,395m. FY17 guidance for approximately €3bn EBIT – is modestly below MSe of €3,120m (+23%), but in line with the consensus median at €2,980m.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

It's been a week of fretting about dividends. Tough to identify anything safe and not 2% right now.

BE11:23am

Revenue: Total 3Q17 revenue of €6,617m compared to MSe €6,766m, and equated to a 2.0% increase YoY. Cargo revenue was strong at 7.9%, helped by volume increases and also by a 0.2% reported increase in yield/RTK. Passenger RASK reported of 0.7% in 3Q17. FX was guided to negatively impact revenues by €117m. BA translation FX effects explain the weaker figures YoY. The 3Q17 constant FX RASK rose 2.2% were weaker from the 3.7% at 2Q17 (although Easter was noted to help 2Q17 figures by ~200bp). RASK was sequentially improved for Europe (up 2.4%, vs down 5.9% in 2Q17), better in AMESA (up 0.3%, vs -0.9% in 2Q17) and better in Latam (up 5.3%, vs up 10.2% in 2Q17). North America was down 3.1% vs 0.0% fall in 2Q17.

PM11:24am

Actually, i think I'm wrong to suggest there's any danger to the divi here. It's the otherway round!

11:24 am
BE11:24am

Costs: CASK ex fuel and FX is up 2.5% (however, excluding the impacts of MRO adjustments and other factors the inflation would have been 1.4%). Fuel expenses were down €108m in the quarter. Guidance for a FY17 fuel bill of €4.6bn has slightly increased compared to €4.5bn prior assumption.

BE11:24am

Balance sheet: Cash and equivalents stand at €7,523m vs €6,428m at the end of 2016, with adjusted net debt of €7,183m vs €8,159m. Net debt/EBITDAR adjusted for operating lease liabilities stands at 1.4 (down 0.4x from FY16).

BE11:25am

RBC makes the interesting point that fuel "accounts for more than 100% of the 2YoY profit uplift"

11:25 am
BE11:25am

Of Q3-17’s 2YoY (vs. Q3-15) adjusted EBIT growth of €205m, €391m was assisted by lower 2YoY fuel costs. More sustainably, staff costs fell 6.5% 2YoY on 12.1% 2YoY ASK growth. Over 2013-16, Q3 has delivered 54% of FY EBIT and Q1-3 in aggregate delivered 77%. This sugges ts FY17E is on track for ~€3.1m EBIT vs. RBCe €3,078m. For FY17E, IAG sees ‘around €3bn’ operating profit – while consensus sees €2.98bn median outlook. We see a low chance of any meaningful EPS upgrades to consensus as a result.

BE11:26am

Our view on IAG shares - EPS momentum is key to legacy airlines – IAG has trailed other legacy airline shares so far during 2017E. While IAG shares are up 52% ytd vs. FTSE100 up 5%, but vs. alternative European airline investments IAG shareholders have suffered an opportunity cost of not being invested in (much) better performing shares. In terms of hard data, year to date AFKLM shares are up 166% (with no DPS yield), Finnair +178%, Lufthansa +124% and SAS +89%.

Absence of material upgrades (we think at most 3-4% is possible to consensus) of the same scale of 10-15% we think Lufthansa consensus is in the midst of, and compared to those seen at AFKLM is likely to leave the shares relatively lagging, even in an improving industry backdrop for mainland Europe. IAG shares trade at 5.0x 2018E EV/EBITDAR (vs. LHA GY before any upgrades at 4.4x 2018E), with IAG shares offering a ~6% equity FCF yield (vs. AFKLM at ~5%, Lufthansa at 4% 2018E/13% pre Air Berlin, potentially rising to over 18% in 2019E even as its capex rises).

BE11:26am

Sector wise, we have Easyjet following ........

You know how stocks here go up when we get Krona-ish action?

PM11:27am

Weak sterling, strong footsie

PM11:28am

Well UBS are arguing that won't necessarily be the case going forward

11:28 am
PM11:28am

Im not sure I quite get this, but let me share quickly

PM11:28am

Another UK market dislocation coming up
A recent return of UK inflation and, importantly, the onset of the first hiking cycle in 10 years will likely lead to a dislocation in the negative relationship between sterling and UK equities. Weaker sterling will likely fail to support UK equities in the period ahead.

PM11:28am

A built-in insurance, thus far
When it comes to the FTSE 100, the FX sensitivity is there by design, as it originates from the make-up of the index: c.75% of revenues comes from overseas. This is not a recent feature of this index, as exporters have made up approximately half of the index steadily over the past 25 years, with the financial sector becoming progressively more internationalized (Figure 1). So, the established market belief is that a weaker currency would support the UK equity market, acting—at least partially—as built-in insurance against domestic sources of risk. This is not inconsequential, at least optically: since the EU referendum, inlocal terms, FTSE 100, S&P 500 & EURO STOXX 50 total returns are the same. But, it is neither an automatic equity market relief.

11:28 am
PM11:29am

Data says yes, market says nothing there
Simple correlations between the FTSE 100 and sterling suggest that a) indeed, recently, this negative correlation re-emerged; b) it is not a given; and, c) tends to snap back quickly (Figure 2). Accounting for global factors (correlation conditional on S&P 500) suggests that in the last thirty years, the impact from a weaker currency is either—statistically indistinguishable from—zero or, less often, negative (Figure 3). For 2018, the market currently anticipates a flat trade-weighted (TW) sterling and is priced for the continuation of the negative FX-equity feedback. We are forecasting weakness (-5.5% TW) and no equity market reprieve on this count.

PM11:29am

Three reasons why weaker sterling is unlikely to be equity supportive ahead
So, why now? Three interrelated reasons. First, the emergence of inflation, especially if linked to past depreciation, complicates firm costs and adversely affects local real demand. Less strictly, lack of inflation pressures is conducive to the FX/equity negative correlation (Figure 4). Second, rising inflation has been followed promptly by tighter monetary policy (Figure 5). In nearly all cases with large negative correlation, the benefit was disrupted by the advent of rising rates; in the ERM crisis, policy was loose and inflation was low and falling. Finally, there is also the 'too-much-of-a-good-thing' syndrome. Too much cumulative depreciation raises uncertainty, in turn, weighing against the benefits of contemporaneous depreciation. When it exceeds 20% within a year, a non-linearity reduces or reverses the negative UK correlation (Figure 6). All three are familiar to long-standing investors in EM, where they are a lot faster & more violent.

PM11:29am

I need to go back and read through that properly.

11:30 am
PM11:30am

But my assumption had always been that UK stocks are really valued in $$, so when sterling falls, nominal stock prices rise.

BE11:03am

BE11:35am

We had included 8p/share risked for this well in our base NAV of
200p/share. Near-term focus will now turn to the development plans for Ghana following the positive ITLOS ruling, progress on the refinancing of Tullow’s reserve base lending facility and the medium-term plans for its East Africa portfolio (Kenya and Uganda). We expect an update on these areas in Tullow's upcoming trading statement on November 8th. Tullow remains a high-beta play among the European Mid-Cap Oils given its high leverage (despite the recent rights issue) and therefore the equity story continues to be very dependent on a recovery in oil prices.

BE11:35am

Drilling to re-start by early January in Ghana — Following the favourable ITLOS ruling, Tullow plans to re-start drilling offshore Ghana by early January. The drilling programme is still being finalised, but we expect initial wells will be focused on the TEN asset to increase production towards the FPSO design capacity of 80kb/d (currently producing c. 50kb/d). However, Tullow could also look to add further well capacity at the Jubilee field to extend the production plateau once the Full Field Development plan has been approved.

11:35 am
BE11:36am

Balance sheet refinancing targeted for year-end — Tullow has launched the refinancing of its reserve-based lending (RBL) facility to extend maturities and reset covenants. We forecast net debt of US$3.7bn at year-end and a new US$2.5bn RBL facility would leave Tullow with liquidity of c. US$1bn. We expect the process will be successful given the reduction in leverage in 2017 following the recent equity raise and organic FCF generation. Cashflow in 2018 will be underpinned by hedging (c. 40% of production at $51/bbl) and Jubilee insurance proceeds (at $60/bbl) that should see Tullow generate FCF of c. US$0.3-0.4bn at c. $55/bbl on our estimates.

BE11:36am

And CS.

BE11:36am

Limited readthrough from Guyana, Suriname is a different play: We see 2 main takeaways from Araku: 1) shallow-water prospects in the region may not work and TLW may need to target deeper prospects, 2) presence of gas condensate highlights risk of a gas charge from deeper Jurassic layers (in other words, Suriname may be 'gassy'), 3) Suriname and Guyana may have different source kitchen, with Canje acting as source for the former.

11:36 am
BE11:37am

Guessing "source kitchen" is an oil industry term.

BE11:37am

LW's approach to exploration: Development drilling remains a priority for TLW, with a focus on FCF generation and subsequent deleveraging. Exploration strategy will remain opportunistic i.e. TLW will seek to drill shallower plays at a cost of $10-15mn net per well. We believe exploration comes for free in TLW at current valuations.

BE11:42am

BE11:43am

RBS reported adj. operating profit for 3Q17 of £1,245m. Further adjusting for the one-off items in slide 10 of the presentation and ~£65m in one off net interest income reported in the margin disclosures we have adj. PBT at £1,006m, 5% below consensus. The Go-Forward Bank – which we define as the group less Capital Resolution, Central & W&G – delivered £1,174m in profit, 8% below UBSe, driven by Commercial and UK PBB where in both cases loan losses were higher than we expected. Risk elements in lending were down 3% QoQ to £9bn / 2.7% of loans from 2.8% QoQ.

11:43 am
BE11:43am

The cost reduction plans have a long way to run, the risk restructuring of RBS is nearing an end with CET1 reporting at 15.5% compared with consensus at 15.3% and Capital Resolution RWAs ex Alawwal at £16.1bn of group RWAs of £211bn. TNAV of 298p was 1% below consensus. No meaningful provisions were booked for legacy issues in 3Q17 though the guidance for a stated profit in 2018 comes subject to the caveat of "providing substantially for DoJ investigation into historic RMBS related activities in 2017". A 4Q17 true-up of provisions may be required, in our view, provided progress can be made in finalising the likely settlement.

BE11:44am

Management unsurprisingly reiterated existing targets for 2017 (cost reduction, RWA run-down) and beyond. For 2020 RBS aims to deliver a stated ROTE above 12% with a sub 50% cost/income ratio and an assumed CET1 capital level of 13%. We think this is consensus with stated EPS of 30-33p per share: if successful this would put RBS on 8.8x 2020 EPS compared with the European bank index on 9.4x.

BE11:44am

On our numbers RBS is trading at 11.3x 2018 EPS, 1.0x TNAV for a forecast ROTE of 9%. We value RBS by sum-of-the-parts using peer group divisional multiples.

undefined
BE11:57am

On the leisure side, RBC pushing Compass.

11:56 am
BE11:57am

Compass is a quality business and the recent under-performance since June (-10% vs FTSE 100) provides a good buying opportunity. We think trading will remain strong, and in a sector context, Compass is one of the more attractively valued defensive growth plays. We upgrade to Outperform and raise our target price from 1530p to 1750p.

BE11:57am

Recent under-performance and valuation discount to peers - The stock has not only underperformed the FTSE 100 of late (-10% since June), but has also underperformed other defensive growth stocks in the sector. This has now left Compass trading on a material valuation discount to these peers, which we see as harsh. In a sector with little value at present (and a number of risky recovery plays), we believe Compass is a sensible place to be on a relative basis.

Trading robust - Organic revenue growth accelerated to 5% in Q3 (ex Easter) and we would expect a similar print in Q4 (excluding any hurricane impact). We expect US growth to remain strong, given Compass's strong competitive advantages and a very promising pipeline. European growth has improved and with better GDP and employment data of late, there is scope for further acceleration going forward. Whilst the ROW remains weak, comparatives are benign going into 2018 and we would expect a return to organic growth. Margin focus remains strong and we forecast 5-10bp improvement a year driven by efficiency gains , with the potential for some operational leverage should LFL growth pick up. FY results on 21 Nov should be a positive catalyst.

CEO change - Richard Cousins has undoubtedly done a great job. However, the strategy and MAP performance framework is well embedded and management bench strength is very strong. We see no reason to believe his departure will meaningfully impact the group and think Dominic Blakemore will be an excellent successor, given his background in the industry with both financial and operational experience.

Fundamentals very strong in a sector context - Investors are getting a rare combination of above-average organic growth, improving margins and strong ROIC. This reflects the outsourcing trend, scale benefits that it possesses, discipline around costs and capital allocation and positive working capital dynamics. The balance sheet remains strong and keeping gearing at 1.5x, we see scope for £2.3bn (9% of market cap) of excess cash over the next 3yrs - 17% including the ord dividend.

Forecasts and valuation - We have tweaked forecasts for recent currency moves - changes are immaterial, although CFPS goes up for higher depreciation. Headline valuations are not cheap, but we feel justified given the strength of the equity story. Our DCF valuation moves from 1530p to 1750p to reflect the higher cashflow forecasts.

Compass Group PLC (CPG:LSE): Last: 1,640, up 39.9 (+2.49%), High: 1,641, Low: 1,616, Volume: 1.68m
